clinical_study.brief_title: DIVAs Perception: Difficult IV Access - Assessment of Patient Understanding
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of Patient Understanding and Preference of Rescue Venous Access When Shown a Narrated Video Vignette Versus Traditional Paper Information Sheet

brief_summary.textblock: Aim: Patient Perception: This aim broadly intends to use traditional script versus a brief video education vignette to determine understanding and preferences among general emergency department patients of rescue access techniques. A challenge of emergency care is providing patient education surrounding procedures in a standardized and patient-oriented manner. This data would provide insight on a patient's understanding of the risks and benefits of rescue access, assess patient preference, and potentially influence what rescue technique is employed in the future. This information may also give us insight onto why DIVA patients might refuse randomization.

primary_outcome.description: Assess patients' understanding of and preferences regarding emergency department procedures: ultrasound-guided IV access and intra-osseous access.

arm_group.description: Patients in this group will be shown an informational video, narrated in English.
Patients in this group will read a single-page printed information sheet in English.

intervention.other_name: Patients will complete a survey to assess their understanding and preferences.

study_pop.textblock: Eligible for enrollment would be any hemodynamically stable adult 18 years of age or older who is a HUP Emergency Department patient, able to provide informed consent, without history of difficult intravenous access, and able to speak, read, hear, and speak English fluently.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- greater than or equal to 18 years of age
- fluent in English
- hemodynamically stable emergency department patient
Exclusion Criteria:
- history of or current status of difficult intravenous access
